bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, June 22, 1929

div1.p: [Carter] writes Russell about a final meeting with Frost before he leaves the country, and describes work she needs to do on Photostats and maps before Frost returns.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, June 22, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel.
Report,
Russell
“Dunlora,” Box 453,
Chrlottesville, Virginia.
June 22, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
In pursunce of a telephone message from Dr. Frost, I went over to Baltimore
last Wednesday morning June 19 (on the 7.55 train), taking with me all the material which Dr.
Frost will need when he resumes the final editing of the History of Yellow Fever.
I also took him the very beautifulcopy of Merriam's map of the life zones of the U. S.,
which was made during Father's lifetime for Section 1. Frost already has, in his
safe, the three tracings I had made from the Mexican Codices concerning the much-
discussed year 1 Rabbit (1454).
The only things remaining to be completed before Frost's return are

A: Two photostats (for which I have already made arrangements) of (a) plate 63
of the Book of Chilam Balam of Chumayel and (b) of the excerpt from this plate concerning
the epidemic of 1648. I didn't know which Frost might prefer so had them both done--
for seventy-five cents. Certainly not excessive! They will be turned over to Miss
Brown when completed and she will either send or bring them to me here.

B: Re the filling in of our outline maps, Mr. Weckerly, the Chief Illus-
trator, has been critically ill, and I was not able to see him until a few days ago.
He assures me, however, that there be abundant time for filling in the lettering (in
pencil) before Dr. Frost's return--nothing will be inked in untilit has Frost's visé.
After talking things over with Mr. Weckerly, I decided that I could simplify his work
(and, of course, lessen the time he would have to put on the maps, by putting in about
a week's more work on them myself. I have therefor brought the “geographic” cards
to “Dunlora” with me as well as my long-suffering Remington “portable,” which I have
used so little of late that despite an extensive--and expensive!--“overhauling” I find
I find it far less easy to handle than my Underwood “standard,” as you probably find it
less easy to read.at least until the mechanism for spacing loosens up a litt.e.

After the “geographic cards” go back to Mr. Weckerly, there will be--so far as I
can see--practically nothing else for me to do in connection with the book until Dr.
-2-
Dr.
Frost resumes work on the final editing--about August 1st. he thinks. Dr. Frost
suggests my spending my time during August between Baltimore and “Dunlora,”. This I
shall be glad to do if we find it does not in any way retard the work on the MS. Of
course, if we find that there seems even the [unclear]test possibility of this, I shall at
once move back to Washington. My apartment there is available at any moment as I
refused to sub-let it even for a few weeks lest I relieve the present double financial “output”
at the greater cost of not being ready for any eventuality in connection with the book.

It was an unspeakable relief to get here last night, the first time (save one
week-end last October) that I've been out of either Baltimore or Washington for twenty-
three months. Washington has been horribly hot of late, and though I worked with an
electric fan whenever practicable, I am considerably “the worse for wear” and very
glad to get away.

With very best remembrances, in which Mrs. Darling (to whom I 'phoned this morn-
ing asks to be included)
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation
61 Broadway,
New York,
N. Y.
